verses.verse: I am the rose <WH2261> of Sharon, <WH8289> and the lily <WH7799> of the valleys. <WH6010>
As the lily <WH7799> among <WH996> thorns, <WH2336> so <WH3651> is my love <WH7474> among <WH996> the daughters. <WH1323>

As the apple <WH8598> tree <WH6086> among the trees <WH6086> of the wood, <WH3293> so <WH3651> is my beloved <WH1730> among <WH996> the sons. <WH1121> I sat <WH3427> down under his shadow <WH6738> with great delight, <WH2530> and his fruit <WH6529> was sweet <WH4966> to my taste. <WH2441>
He brought <WH935> me to the banqueting <WH3196> house, <WH1004> and his banner <WH1714> over <WH5921> me was love. <WH160>
Stay <WH5564> me with flagons, <WH809> comfort <WH7502> me with apples: <WH8598> for I am sick <WH2470> of love. <WH160>
His left <WH8040> hand <WH8040> is under <WH8478> my head, <WH7218> and his right <WH3225> hand <WH3225> does embrace <WH2263> me.

I charge <WH7650> you, O you daughters <WH1323> of Jerusalem, <WH3389> by the roes, <WH6643> and by the hinds <WH355> of the field, <WH7704> that you stir <WH5782> not up, nor <WH518> awake <WH5782> my love, <WH160> till <WH5704> he please. <WH2654>
The voice <WH6963> of my beloved! <WH1730> behold, <WH2009> he comes <WH935> leaping <WH1801> on the mountains, <WH2022> skipping <WH7092> on the hills. <WH1389>

My beloved <WH1730> is like <WH1819> a roe <WH6643> or <WH176> a young <WH6082> hart: <WH354> behold, <WH2009> he stands <WH5975> behind <WH310> our wall, <WH3796> he looks <WH7688> forth at <WH4480> the windows, <WH2474> showing <WH6692> himself through <WH4480> the lattice. <WH2762>
My beloved <WH1730> spoke, <WH6030> and said <WH559> to me, Rise <WH6965> up, my love, <WH7474> my fair <WH3302> one, and come <WH3212> away.
For, see, <WH2009> the winter <WH5638> is past, <WH5674> the rain <WH1653> is over <WH2498> and gone; <WH1980>

The flowers <WH5339> appear <WH7200> on the earth; <WH776> the time <WH6256> of the singing <WH2158> of birds is come, <WH5060> and the voice <WH6963> of the turtle <WH8449> is heard <WH8085> in our land; <WH776>

The fig <WH8384> tree puts <WH2590> forth <WH2590> her green <WH6291> figs, <WH6291> and the vines <WH1612> with the tender grape <WH5563> give <WH5414> a good smell. <WH7381> Arise, <WH6965> my love, <WH7474> my fair <WH3302> one, and come <WH3212> away.

O my dove, <WH3123> that are in the clefts <WH2288> of the rock, <WH5553> in the secret <WH5643> places of the stairs, <WH4095> let me see <WH7200> your countenance, <WH4758> let me hear <WH8085> your voice; <WH6963> for sweet <WH6149> is your voice, <WH6963> and your countenance <WH4758> is comely. <WH5000>
Take <WH270> us the foxes, <WH7776> the little <WH6996> foxes, <WH7776> that spoil <WH2254> the vines: <WH3754> for our vines <WH3754> have tender grapes. <WH5563>
My beloved <WH1730> is mine, and I am his: he feeds <WH7462> among the lilies. <WH7799>

Until <WH5704> the day <WH3117> break, <WH6315> and the shadows <WH6752> flee <WH5127> away, turn, <WH5437> my beloved, <WH1730> and be you like <WH1819> a roe <WH6643> or <WH176> a young <WH6082> hart <WH354> on the mountains <WH2022> of Bether. <WH1336>
